Vladimir Bossicard wrote:
> 
> > - JUnit should be the stable angle for the very unstable projects we all
> > have to do. Changing too much jeopardizes stableness.
> 
> The major complains users have do not target the framework but the swing
> or text interface.  Adding functionalities like "managing the non-loaded
> classes" via properties do not add (too much) complexity to the
> framework.
right.

> Share your work!  If you write things you thing is really interesting,
> share it!  Don't expect 2-3 people to have the solution for every
> problem you encounter :-)

I share my work - but as an extension to JUnit. That was my point.

> 
> > That's why I'd rather have JUnit as a core with hooks to plug in
> > additional behaviour which is available in additional tools.
> 
> I partially agree.  If you have too many additional tools to run a
> program, you will have conflicts with versions.  I think that JUnit must
> have a framework, a swing interface and a text interface.
> 
> I proposed the architecture of "plug-in" modules that will enable other
> programmers to write specific "TestResult" modules (using XML,
> databases, mail to store the results).  This won't add complexity to
> JUnit and allow a great flexibility.

The plug-in architecture sounds very good to me. I'm looking forward to
it.

Johannes
